title: Showing Up: The Power of Presence
devotional:
Old Man Hemlock, as the townsfolk affectionately called him, wasn't known for his sermons. In fact, Hemlock rarely spoke at all, save for the occasional gruff greeting or request at the local market. Yet, every Sunday, without fail, Hemlock sat in the same pew, three rows from the back, a silent sentinel in the community of believers. He wasn't a greeter, didn't sing in the choir, and certainly didn't participate in the after-service coffee hour. Many assumed he was simply a lonely soul, clinging to tradition. 

One Sunday, a fierce storm raged, and only a handful of congregants braved the elements. Among them was Hemlock, soaked to the bone but present nonetheless. Sarah, a young woman new to the church, found herself unexpectedly moved by his dedication. She hesitantly sat beside him. The sermon was short, the music even shorter, and as people quickly dispersed, Sarah, feeling bold, asked Hemlock, "Mr. Hemlock, why do you come every week, even in this weather? You don't seem to... participate much."

Hemlock looked at her, his eyes, usually hidden behind a veil of age, sparkled with a surprising warmth. He rasped, "I come for the knowing, girl. Knowing I ain't alone. Knowing we're all in this together, rain or shine. This here ain't just a building; it's a raft. And we need each other to stay afloat."

His words struck Sarah deeply. She had been so focused on active participation, on outward displays of faith, that she'd missed the profound power of simply being present, of offering silent support and solidarity. Hemlock's quiet faithfulness wasn't about performance; it was about belonging, about reinforcing the bonds of fellowship that held the community together. It was a silent sermon about the importance of showing up, of being a consistent, reliable presence in the lives of others, offering a steady anchor in the storms of life.

The story of Old Man Hemlock reminds us that fellowship isn't always about grand gestures or eloquent pronouncements. Sometimes, it's simply about showing up, about being present in the lives of our brothers and sisters in Christ, offering silent support and a sense of belonging. It's about recognizing that we are all part of the same body, and that each member, regardless of their outward contributions, plays a vital role in the health and strength of the whole.
image_description: An empty wooden church pew with raindrops visible on the window in the background.
insights: The importance of fellowship is emphasized throughout the New Testament. Hebrews 10:24-25 urges us to 'consider how we may spur one another on toward love and good deeds, not giving up meeting together, as some are in the habit of doing, but encouraging one another—and all the more as you see the Day approaching.' This passage highlights the active role we play in encouraging and supporting one another within the community of believers. Additionally, 1 Corinthians 12:25-26 reminds us that 'there should be no division in the body, but that its parts should have equal concern for each other. If one part suffers, every part suffers with it; if one part is honored, every part rejoices with it.'
prayer: Heavenly Father, thank you for the gift of fellowship, for the brothers and sisters you have placed in my life. Help me to recognize the importance of simply being present, of offering silent support and encouragement to those around me. Teach me to see the value in every member of the body of Christ, and to appreciate the unique contributions that each person brings. Help me to be a faithful and reliable presence in the lives of others, a source of comfort and strength in times of need. In Jesus' name, Amen.
reflection: How can you be a more consistent and reliable presence in the lives of your fellow believers? Are there members of your community who may be feeling isolated or alone? What small act of fellowship can you offer them today? How can you shift your focus from outward displays of faith to the simple act of showing up and being present for others?
